review_comments.body: It would not pose a problem and make the code simpler. With static I have to get the component's page and ran into a order problem of removing the behavior from the page and trying to change the page's meta data. The dangling reference is only a problem when you have memory constraints, but then the lazyloadpanel's reference would not be your biggest problem. Regardless I've changed it to be static.
Fixed it by tracking the panels directly.
oopsie, this one should've been removed.

Can't. The timer is a single instance for all ALLP's on a page. The reason for using just one timer is that when you have more, you get a barrage of events fired at your server and you don't want that (I've seen the horror). A single timer is the best compromise for this. I've thought about increasing the timer the longer the wait takes, but decided against it because as a user you want direct feedback. A timer of a second is a rather nice compromise between request pressure on the server and wait time for the user.
The `ALLT` is per-page. Perhaps we can check if the Page implements a special settings interface e.g. `IAjaxLazyLoadTimerSettings` and retrieve the duration from that?

No, as `isReadyForReplacement()` is actually there for preventing replacement prematurely. Why would you wait until some time in the future to do the replacement when you can replace now and the component is ready for replacement?

issue_comments.body: WICKET-3975 is fixed. The ball is back in your field ;-)

The patches look good to me.

-tests.jar is produced by http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-jar-plugin/jar-mojo.html
-test-sources.jar by http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-source-plugin/test-jar-mojo.html
Both of them automatically append their suffixes to the configured 'finalName' setting. So it seems it is not possible to tweak them :-/

a) don't put them in the parent pom because they are not used by all modules. I'll clean that after applying your patch.
b) attach the patch to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/WICKET-3976

Following Apache rules we have to wait the vote to end. Looking at the current votes I'm sure approach 2) will win so your work wont be lost.
If you don't want to wait then you can create a new branch on top of this one. You'll need just to add the new module in the parent pom, everything else will be in the new folder wicket-osgi, so I think it wont be hard for you to rebase after this patch is applied. But wicket-osgi can be added at any time so it is not urgent at all :-)
Thanks for your contributions!

Hi,

Wicket Native WebSocket module is no more experimental since 6.14 - https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/WICKET-5488.
We may break the API only in 7.x branch if you (our users) suggest something that is not achievable without the break.

Strings.replaceAll() returns CharSequence.

save() puts the cookie in the WebResponse.
the calls later just override whatever the CookieDefaults has set on the _same_ Cookie instance.
The cookie itself is written to the http response much later, when the WebResponse is flushed.

org.apache.wicket.MarkupContainer#internalInitialize is executed to decide whether a page is stateless or not at org.apache.wicket.Page#isPageStateless, so I think it may call several times `onReAdd()` unless we introduce this new flag. It should be set to false in `onRemove()`

reset `onReAddCalled` to false and call `page.internalInitialize()`
verify that `onReAddCalled` is still false. `onReAdd()` should not be called until the component is removed and added again to the tree

Yeah, that's why I moved them to the test application and removed MediaUtils.java.
Different applications will need different set of those, so they can add only the ones they need.

The test that checks for XML well formness is from the time when Wicket tried to support XHTML.
I like the test because being well formed XML makes the rendering of the HTML predictable in different browsers. In the past if you have non-closed `<div>` some browsers were rendering very weird layout.
The test guarantees that Wicket's own .html files are XML valid ones. But there is nothing in Wicket that does this for application markup files.
There is IMarkupFilter that auto-closes some HTML tags for you, but that's all. If there is an error in your markup you would see it at runtime ...

My idea is to reduce the noise and the memory consumption.

pull_requests.title: WICKET-6427 Fire an event once all ajax timers are registered
pull_requests.body: Fire Wicket.Event.Topic.AJAX_TIMERS_BOUND event once all Wicket.Timer.set() calls are executed

pull_requests.title: Wicket 6498 deferred javascript made simple
pull_requests.body:
This is a much simpler solution than #253: Applications can just use a JavaScriptDeferHeaderResponse and that's it.

Application has to be changed slightly in its handling of IHeaderResponseDecorators: there's always a decorator that applies a ResourceAggregator - this enables us to chain a header response *behind* the ResourceAggregator.
This simplifies JavaScriptFilteredIntoFooterHeadResponse too, since it no longer has to worry about dependencies.

pull_requests.title: WICKET-6517 ajax multipart
pull_requests.body: With this change multipart Ajax requests *are* send via Ajax.

pull_requests.title: WICKET-6498 deferred javascript
pull_requests.body:
If addEventListener is used instead of jQuery  "domready" and "load" events, and OnLoadHeaderItem instead of JavaScriptHeaderItem, all JavaScript resources can be deferred.

Open questions:
- does this solution work reliably on all browsers?
- who decides which JavaScript resources to defer and which not?
- how to handle cases where user code is still using a JavaScriptHeaderItem?

pull_requests.title: experimenting with suspension of requestCycle via servlet 3 async
pull_requests.body:
Let's discuss how Wicket could support async processing.

Idea is to allow suspending the current RequestCycle,  example's LinkPage shows the usage.

Notes:
- async-supported has to be enabled on the filter in web.xml (I did so for ComponentReferenceApplication)
- pageAccessSynchronizer uses the requestCycle now instead of the thread 
, since two threads might process the same pages *successively* - is that a valid approach?(PageAccessSynchronizerTest has to be adapted)
- I changed ServletWebRequest to use its own contextPath instead of calling httpServletRequest#getContextPath(), since the latter returns null during async processing

review_comments.body: I find IModel<?>... highly unusual for a Wicket component. Shouldn't that be IModel<List<?>> ?
This should probably be static to prevent a dangling reference to the surrounding component.

Counting all loading panels might be problematic: What if one (or one of its parents) is removed from the component hierarchy? The timer will keep requesting until forever.
How about broadcasting the AjaxLazyLoadTimer to all components, giving them the opportunity to keep the timer running?

```
((AjaxLazyLoadTimer)event.getPayload()).notReadyForReplacement();
```

If any of the panels is not ready yet, the timer has to keep running.

Shouldn't #onEvent() check for a specific event? If other events are sent through the component hierarchy (e.g. when any other Ajax request is processed), the lazy component might be replaced prematurely.

pull_requests.title: Replace filterPath pattern '/*' with empty string
pull_requests.body:
A filterPath pattern of '/*' is now replaced with an empty string. This matches the behavior of methods getFilterPathFromAnnotation() and getFilterPathFromConfig().

I'm not sure if it's a bug, but I noticed the different beahvior when initializing Wicket in a Spring Boot application. When using a @WebFilter("/*") annotation or the init parameter filterMappingUrlPattern="/*" Wicket works as expected, but when doing the same programmatically with wicketFilter.setFilterPath("/*") the path gets internally rewritten to "*/" and Wicket than only handles HTTP requests to the root path.

pull_requests.title: Error page redirection support for autocomplete ajax response
pull_requests.body:
Autocomplete field resulting an exception with 
org.apache.wicket.settings.ExceptionSettings#errorHandlingStrategyDuringAjaxRequests, 
set to 
org.apache.wicket.settings.ExceptionSettings.AjaxErrorStrategy.REDIRECT_TO_ERROR_PAGE

does not redirect to the error page.

This fix will enable page redirection even for autocomplete field.

Forgot to publish
This is now re-design in Pull 48

Because of the issue with the 6.9.0 release and the revert for 6.9.1 I added the ability to enable and disable the anonymous and non-static inner class injection by having the AbstractCdiContainer implementation verify the feature is supported.  In the cdi-weld package, the WeldCdiContainer class checks the specification-version in the manifest of the jar containing WeldBootstrap.class.  If the value is 2.0.2.Final or later the support for anonymous and non-static inner class injection is enabled.  If the version is less than 2.0.2.Final the support is disabled. Also added ability to disable it regardless of version by including the proper init params to the CdiWicketFilter.

Well Glassfish 4 still uses 2.0.0.sp1. I say we leave it until Glassfish4
is well past sp1. Once sp1 is non longer used then we can just remove it.
 This is the nice part of leaving it in the experimental package IMO. Also
the pattern to implement that feature is also designed to expose container
specific features in the future. I designed it as it is to have a mechanism
to allow the core to ask the implementation for support of container
specific features.  When openwebbeans supports cdi 1.1 we may have to
handle some things slightly different and it is nice to already have the
code to do that.

It just disables anonymous inner class and non-static inner class injection
if not supported.  Everything else is injected like normal. Personally I
have yet to find a use case where I needed to put @Inject in an anonymous
or non-static inner.  In both of those cases putting the @Inject at the top
level works just fine, and unit testable. If anyone could show me a good
reason why it makes since to @Inject in the anonymous or no-static inner
class then I am all ears.

As for the stderr, the code log.warns that the feature is not supported by
${specification-title} ${specification-version} the first time it is
attempted.

John

still supports cdi-1.0 code. It now allows injection at the instantiation
of the App, it supports the Auto with a finer granularity.  To me it is
still your code with some assistance from me to get it to 1.1.

John

In the latest revision, the AutoConversation is supported.  Just add
@Conversational to the class.  If you want to do it the cdi-1.0 way then
implement ConversationalComponent as , which was modified to have the
@Conversational annotation. The Conversational annotation also adds some
properties, prop and auto.  prop allows the reconfiguration of the
ConversationPropagation for the particular Page without affecting the
global ConversationPropagation set at the Application Instantiation.  The
auto property allows for the Page to override the auto property set
globally by the Application for the Session.  Nothing broke just allows for
page level reconfiguration.

package org.apache.wicket;
import org.apache.wicket.model.IModel;
/**
 * An interface for all {@link Component components} with type-safe accessors and mutators
 * for the model and its object.
 *

 */
public interface IGenericModel
{
    /**
     * Typesafe getter for the model
     *

     */
    IModel getModel();
    /**
     * Typesafe setter for the model
     *
     * @param model
     *            the new model
     * @return This for chaining
     */
    Component setModel(IModel model);
    /**
     * Typesafe setter for the model object
     *
     * @param object
     *            the new model object
     * @return This for chaining
     */
    Component setModelObject(T object);
    /**
     * Typesafe getter for the model's object
     *
     * @return the model object
     */
    T getModelObject();
}
--- The IGenericComponent is for use for generic Model so the new name IGenericModel would fit better i think

The php scripts can be thrown away after the merge of this commits because then the documentation should be updated in the .adoc files and not in the .gdoc files anymore. 

To start converting all the gdoc files to adoc you need to pass all the gdoc files through the `adoccommandline.php`. `run.sh` is doing that, it's searching all the gdoc files in guide/ and convert it to adoc format in asciidoc/. So the first step is run `$ ./run.sh`. 

The next step is that there should be one index.adoc file which include all the other adoc files. Gdoc has toc.yml but asciidoc need a completely other syntax. `toctoindex.php` loads guide/toc.yml and give an output that should be index.adoc. To do that, run `$ ./toctoindex.php > asciidoc/index.adoc`.

If that's done, run `$ mvn` in `wicket-user-guide` to render index.adoc to index.html and index.pdf with all adoc files included. In `wicket-user-guide/target/generated-docs` is the result. Ignore the empty directories.

I hope this will help. Thanks for your comment!

Hi Martin,

renderAll was overwritten by us to add some performance profiling, something like this:
<startPerfProfiling>
super.renderAll()
<stopPerfProfiling>

addStateChange() was overwritten to prevent the increment of a page version number, since we manipulated the component hierarchy after rendering, but before the page gets stored. This is a very deep manipulation of Wicket, we are fully aware of that, but it was essential for our high traffic scenario.

Be careful here.  HttpSession has no defined behavior or scope once the HTTP connection has been upgraded into WebSocket.   It is 100% valid for the HttpServletRequest, HttpServletResponse, and HttpSession to be recycled immediately after the connection has been upgraded (as you are no longer HTTP).
